title.narrative: Mapped in Bangladesh (MiB): RMG Factory Mapping Project by CED-BRACU

description.narrative:
Mapped in Bangladesh (MiB) is a 4-year research initiative by BRAC University that aims to map the export-oriented ready-made garment (RMG) industry across all garment-producing districts in the country. MiB’s design and implementation is in response to the lack of essential sector data, such as, the actual number of factories that exist in the country, the number of male/female workers employed there, the kind of products they produce, the brands that work with them, etc.
In line with the nation’s “Digital Bangladesh Vision 2021”, with the MiB tool, the RMG industry is expected to come one step closer to aligning itself to the mandated digitization of every sector. MiB (formerly “DRFM-B” – Digital RMG Factory Mapping in Bangladesh) is being implemented by BRAC University’s Centre for Entrepreneurship Development (CED) and coordinated by BRAC. The project is funded by Laudes Foundation with the co-funding by the Kingdom of the Netherlands (through EKN – Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands).
Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Association (BGMEA) and Bangladesh Knitwear Manufacturers and Exporters Association (BKMEA) are the strategic partners of the project. The project is also supported by Department of Inspection for Factories and Establishments (DIFE) under the Ministry of Labour and Employment of the Government of Bangladesh.

MiB endeavors to do census of all the export-oriented ready-made garment (RMG) factories in Bangladesh and to provide accurate, credible and updated factory data that can generate various reports for major stakeholders, like brands and buyers, to make informed business decisions.

The key target impact that the project seeks to achieve is the launch of a transparency mechanism used by the industry. This is the first ever project to digitally map the sector and provide an opportunity to understand the universe of export-oriented RMG factories in Bangladesh. The Project, through its mapping and relationship building, will fuel Bangladesh’s RMG industry advancements and inspire shared responsibility and collective action.
Mapped in Bangladesh can serve as an example for progress in the global garment industry, by taking into account what is learned in Bangladesh and applying it on an even larger scale. Mapped in Bangladesh strives to ensure the “Made in Bangladesh” brand represents the future of manufacturing ready-made garments, where strengthened and responsible practices are the norm.

The objective of Mapped in Bangladesh is to provide accurate, credible and updated RMG factory information to all industry stakeholders in a manner that enables greater efficiency, productivity, accountability and transparency. Designed and built in Bangladesh, this powerful tool serves as a home-grown solution that further strengthens the country’s significant and thriving RMG industry.
The project aims to collect primary data about the export-oriented RMG industry and disclose information to the public in the form of an interactive online map. Driven by a collective action approach, Mapped in Bangladesh seeks input from all stakeholders through its crowd-sourcing platform, in order to keep the data accurate and up-to-date.
Because of the growing need for credible, industry-wide data on the number of factories, their locations, number of workers, and much more, challenges remain across the Bangladesh RMG industry. This project is the first of its kind, providing a detailed industry-wide database of export-oriented RMG factories on an interactive, digital map (similar to Google Maps). This new platform is publicly accessible in order to catalyze transparency and bring about meaningful industry improvements in Bangladesh, and thus strengthen the sector as a whole.

activity-date.narrative: The planned end date for the project is on 30 June 2021.
The project officially started its operation on 15 April 2017.

recipient-country.narrative: The project is being implemented across the country.

sector.narrative: Digital mapping of all the export-oriented ready-made garment (RMG) factories in Bangladesh.

Center for Critical and Qualitative Studies (CQS) of the University of Liberal Arts Bangladesh (ULAB) was hired for MiB Midline Evaluation and the report is scheduled to be finalized by July 2020.

title.narrative: Mid-line Evaluation Report of MiB Project

description.narrative: Center for Critical and Qualitative Studies (CQS) of University of Liberal Arts Bangladesh (ULAB), as a consultant, started working on the Mid-line Evaluation of MiB from 11 November 2019. In February 2020, CQS provided the first draft of the Mid-line Evaluation Report. CED worked on the report, and sent it back to CQS with the feedback of related project personnel in March 2020. In April 2020, the updated report (second draft) was sent to the funder for adding feedback from Ms Savi Mull (Senior Evaluation Manager, Laudes Foundation). The process of finalizing the report; however, was affected by the COVID19 situation, and was delayed. The submitted draft report was scheduled to be finalized by July 2020.

title.narrative: Media Outreach of Mapped in Bangladesh Project

description.narrative: In order to promote and also for the outreach initiative of MiB, the project has started publishing articles using different printing and electronic media. The project believes that due to the circulation of these articles, more people will learn about the map and use it and thus the outreach purpose of the project will be attained. Apart from publishing articles in national dailies, an international media - Vogue Business has interviewed the Project Manager of the MiB and published an article titled: As coronavirus spreads, supply chain workers face layoffs on March 19, 2020. The interview was conducted and the article was written by Ms. Rachel Cernansky.
This document contains the links to the published articles on various newspapers during 1 Nov 2019 to 30 Jun 2020.

title.narrative: Number and type of media stories published on the digital map (include print and electronic media – social media)

description.narrative: The outreach initiative is a continuous process and till June 30, 2020, a total of seven (7) newspaper articles/ op-eds on MiB project were published in four (4) national dailies. These are: The Daily Sun, Samakal, Dhaka Tribune, The Business Standard, etc. Details of publication can be found in the enclosed document.

title.narrative: Clusters Covered and Factories Presented on the Digital Map

description.narrative: MiB covered total 3 clusters and presented 2837 export-oriented RMG factories on the digital map (2369 member factories; 468 non-member factories) during 1 November 2019 to 30 June 2020.
This is the URL of the website containing the MiB digital map. It presents factory number on an interactive digital map and the factory profiles with essential data points.

title.narrative: Number of Clusters Covered and Number of Export-oriented RMG Factories Presented on the Digital Map

description.narrative: As of 30 June 2020, MiB covered a total of 3 clusters out of the targeted 5 clusters as per project plan. The data collected from the export-oriented RMG factories located in Dhaka, Gazipur and Narayanganj districts (i.e. 3 clusters) were uploaded to the digital map. During November 2019 to June 2020, a total of 311 factories from the 3 clusters were uploaded to the map after completing data verification and validation. Since the inception of the project and till June 2020, the total number of factories uploaded to the map stands as 2837 (2369 member factories; 468 non-member factories).

title.narrative: Stakeholder Engagement through Project Advisory Committee (PAC) Meeting

description.narrative: MiB project is the first of its kind to map export-oriented RMG factories across all garment-producing districts in Bangladesh, providing a detailed industry-wide database of factories, including subcontractors, on an interactive, digital map. In order to undertake such a huge challenge – the project is being guided by a multi-stakeholder Project Advisory Committee (PAC), focused on the stakeholder engagement in the from all relevant and essential entities. PAC includes representatives of workers, NGOs, donors, brand/buyers, employers, industry associations, right-based organization, and government representative(s).

title.narrative: Number of Project Advisory Committee (PAC) Meeting Organized

description.narrative: The last and 5th Project Advisory Committee (PAC) Meeting was organized on 12 December 2019. The 6th PAC meeting was scheduled to be organized in April 2020; however, due to the COVID19, the meeting was postponed. At this point of the pandemic situation, it was not possible to organize the PAC meeting by June 2020, and it is quite uncertain to say the schedule when it would be organized. However, to mitigate this issue, MiB is planning to organize the PAC meeting online, and is communicating with the PAC members for their views on this.

Started in December 2019, the main survey, i.e. the data collection from the RMG factories in Chattogram district (Cluster-4), has 10% data yet to be collected, and MiB had to stop the data collection in March 2020 due to Covid-19.

title.narrative: A Total of 505 Factory Data Collected as of June 2020

description.narrative: In March 2020, after the commencement of nation-wide lockdown due to Covid-19, MiB had to stop its data collection in Chattogram and bring back its Field Supervisors (FS) and Field Officers (FO) to Dhaka (MiB office). After a brief estimation, MiB found that about 90% of Chattogram data have been collected (a total of 505), remaining around 10% at hand, yet to be collected later on after the pandemic situation becomes normal. Since this initiative collects data through census, so there is no target.

title.narrative: User Outreach of the Digital Map

description.narrative: Statistics on the website hosting the map – user traffic; the number of unique visitors as per ISP address; geographical footprint; and click through rates (to the map). Number and type of media stories published on the digital map (including print/electronic/social media).

title.narrative: User Outreach Analytics for Use of Digital Map

description.narrative: Available details on the users who visited the digital map

title.narrative: Number of Disclosure and Transparency Mechanism

description.narrative: From the analytics report , some pointers observed as follows: Total users visited the site (during 1 January to 30 June 2020) are 2,464 with unique page view of total 14,798 (total page view) having average duration each user spent on site was 4:28 min. Most visitors are from Bangladesh (1,434), United States (229), China (179), Japan (123) and India (69). We had 76.4% Male and 23.6% Female from the total visitors. Major age range of the visitors are age 25 to 34 years old. We had 2K+ new users having average session duration of 4:28 min on site. Bounce rate was found approx 65%. We have experienced some visitor spikes around mid of February, end of April and highest spike on the mid of May.
